rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 2:8–32
rsbNotes.text: 2:8–32 Abner’s installation of Saul’s son Ish-bosheth as king over Israel results in war between the houses of Saul and David.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 2:12
rsbNotes.text: 2:12 Gibeon. Gibeon was a Benjaminite town, now called el-Jib, about five miles north of Jerusalem.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 2:13
rsbNotes.text: 2:13 Joab the son of Zeruiah. See note on v. 18.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 2:14
rsbNotes.text: 2:14 Let the young men arise and compete. Abner suggests a form of representative combat similar to the contest between David and Goliath (1 Sam. 17:4 note). Large-scale bloodshed was not averted either time (vv. 17, 31).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 2:18
rsbNotes.text:
2:18 three sons of Zeruiah. According to 1 Chr. 2:16, Zeruiah was one of David’s two sisters, which would make her sons his nephews.

Joab. Joab played an important role throughout David’s reign, serving as commander of David’s forces (8:16). Though an ardent supporter of David, Joab at times proved to be uncontrollable (3:39), acting in his own interests (3:26, 27) and even defying David’s orders (18:5, 9–14). Joab was executed by King Solomon (1 Kin. 2:28–35).

Abishai. Abishai served alongside Joab in David’s army (10:10; 18:2; 23:18).

Asahel. Also listed among David’s mighty men (23:24), Asahel’s relentless pursuit of Abner in this present episode will lead to a violent death (v. 23).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 2:22
rsbNotes.text: 2:22 How then could I . . . your brother Joab. Abner’s attempts to avoid striking down Asahel may be motivated not simply by fear of reprisal from Joab, but also by a desire not to erect unnecessary barriers to eventual compromise with David. See note on v. 26.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 2:26
rsbNotes.text: 2:26 tell your people to turn from the pursuit of their brothers. Abner’s reference to “their brothers” may suggest a shift in a more conciliatory direction; perhaps Abner senses that David cannot be stopped. Abner would prefer truce to defeat, especially if he could remain autonomous.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 2:28
rsbNotes.text: 2:28 trumpet. See note 1 Sam. 13:3.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 2:30–31
rsbNotes.text: 2:30, 31 The disparity between the number of casualties suffered by David’s troops and by the Benjaminites is a token of things to come.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:1
rsbNotes.text: 3:1 war between the house of Saul and the house of David. At least in the northern tribes, the transfer of power to David after the death of Saul was not unopposed. A key figure supporting Saul was Abner, Saul’s military commander who had installed Saul’s surviving son, Ish-bosheth, as king in Mahanaim (2:8, 9). But the tide was running in David’s favor (2:30, 31 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:2–11
rsbNotes.text: 3:2–11 The list of six sons born to David (vv. 2–5) amplifies the statement in v. 1 that “David grew stronger and stronger,” while the wrangling between Abner and Ish-bosheth over a concubine (vv. 6–11) dramatizes the final statement in v. 1 that ‘‘the house of Saul became weaker and weaker.”

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:2
rsbNotes.text: 3:2 sons were born to David at Hebron. As the list that follows reveals, David took additional wives in Hebron. In 5:13–16, after David’s arrival in Jerusalem, yet more wives and concubines are added, and at least eleven more children will be born to David (see the cumulative list in 1 Chr. 3:1–9). While the narrator offers no explicit evaluation of David’s behavior (ancient Near Eastern kings commonly multiplied wives and children), it violates the standards of Deut. 17:17.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:3
rsbNotes.text: 3:3 Maacah the daughter of Talmai king of Geshur. David’s marrying a foreign wife from the small Aramean kingdom of Geshur may have been politically motivated, giving him an ally north of Ish-bosheth’s shaky realm.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:7
rsbNotes.text: 3:7 Why have you gone in to my father’s concubine. Abner’s appropriation of Saul’s concubine would amount to a claim on the throne (12:8 note; 16:21 note; 1 Kin. 2:22). The reader is not told whether Ish-bosheth’s suspicion is well-founded or simple paranoia. Whatever the case, Abner uses the accusation as an occasion to shift his allegiance to David (vv. 8–10).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:9
rsbNotes.text: 3:9 what the Lord has sworn to him. See 5:2 note; 1 Sam. 13:14 note; 15:28; 24:20 note.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:10
rsbNotes.text: 3:10 Dan to Beersheba. A proverbial expression for “the whole country” (Judg. 20:1).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:11
rsbNotes.text: 3:11 he feared him. Ish-bosheth’s reaction indicates that Abner was in a position not only to make a threat but to carry it out.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:12
rsbNotes.text: 3:12 To whom does the land belong. Abner means that the land is his own, as one who controls it and can give it to David, or else that the land is David’s by right, and that David should enlist Abner’s help to secure it.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:13
rsbNotes.text: 3:13 bring Michal, Saul’s daughter. Returning David’s wife Michal to him (1 Sam. 18:27) would not only make right Saul’s wrong of having given her to another in David’s absence (1 Sam. 25:44), but would also strengthen David’s claim to the throne over Saul’s former realm. The restrictions of Deut. 24:1–4 do not apply in this situation, since David’s separation from Michal was involuntary.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:14
rsbNotes.text:
3:14 David sent messengers to Ish-bosheth. The insecurity of Ish-bosheth’s position is evident not only in his fear of Abner (v. 11) but also in his inability to resist David’s orders.

a hundred foreskins of the Philistines. David refers to the bride-price that Saul had set for Michal (1 Sam. 18:25); his payment had actually been twice the amount (1 Sam. 18:27).

weeping. A vivid glimpse of suffering caused by deeds outside the man’s control.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:16
rsbNotes.text: 3:16 Bahurim. Tentatively identified with a site about 1.5 miles east of Jerusalem in the territory of Benjamin. Bahurim was the hometown of Shimei, son of Gera (16:5; 1 Kin. 2:8).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:17
rsbNotes.text: 3:17 you have been seeking David as king over you. See v. 1 note. Apparently Ish-bosheth and Abner are all that have stood in the way of harmonious relations between David and Israel. Abner here steps aside, and Ish-bosheth will not stand long without him (ch. 4).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:18
rsbNotes.text: 3:18 my servant David. David is now recognized as the recipient of a commission like the one first given to Saul (1 Sam. 9:16).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:21
rsbNotes.text:
3:21 that they may make a covenant with you. See 5:3.

in peace. The repetition of this phrase twice more in vv. 22, 23 underscores that David was not involved in Abner’s death; see also vv. 26, 28, 29, 37.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:24
rsbNotes.text: 3:24 Joab’s agitation at the thought of Abner’s peaceful departure is apparent in his words to David.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:26
rsbNotes.text:
3:26 cistern of Sirah. A few miles north of Hebron.

But David did not know about it. This note is another confirmation of David’s innocence in the death of Abner (vv. 21–23, 28, 29, 37).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:27
rsbNotes.text: 3:27 for the blood of Asahel his brother. See also v. 30. In 2:18–23 Abner’s slaying of Asahel is depicted as essentially a matter of self-defense, and the battle context of Abner’s action makes it doubtful that Joab had the right to act as an “avenger of blood” (14:11; Num. 35:16–25; Deut. 19:11–13; Josh. 20:3). Joab may also have wanted to eliminate a potential rival in David’s court (see his murder of Amasa in 20:10).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:28
rsbNotes.text: 3:28 I and my kingdom are forever guiltless. See vv. 21–23, 26, 37.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:29
rsbNotes.text: 3:29 May it fall upon the head of Joab. David’s decision only to utter a curse upon Joab’s house rather than take direct disciplinary action may have been a result of the ambiguous circumstances of Joab’s crime. More likely, however, such factors as Joab’s considerable power and reputation and his familial relationship with David influenced his decision. Ultimately Joab’s crime did not go unpunished (1 Kin. 2:5, 6, 28–35).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 3:39
rsbNotes.text: 3:39 more severe. That is, “too hard” or “ruthless.” See v. 29 note; cf. 16:10; 19:22.
